{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Year nav topic5|1610|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1610'''. <!-- formerly (18apr07): ''See also:'' [[1609 in literature]], [[1610|other events of 1610]], [[1611 in literature]], [[list of years in literature]]. -->
==Events== *[[December 12]] – Sir [[Thomas Bodley]] makes an agreement with the [[Stationers' Company]] of London to put a copy of every book registered with them into his new [[Bodleian Library]] in the [[University of Oxford]].<ref>{{cite book |editor=Nicoll, Allardyce |title=Shakespeare Survey Vol. 4: An Annual Survey of Shakespearean Study & Production |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1951}}</ref> *Completion of publication of the [[Douay–Rheims Bible]] (''The Holie Bible Faithfully Translated into English''), a translation of the [[Bible]] from the [[Latin]] [[Vulgate]] into English made by members of the [[English College, Douai]], in the service of the [[Catholic Church]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Pope |first=Hugh |url=https://archive.org/stream/dublinreview147londuoft#page/96/mode/2up |title=The Origin of the Douay Bible |journal=[[Dublin Review (Catholic periodical) |The Dublin Review]] |location=London |volume=147 |issue=294-295 |date=July–October 1910}}</ref> *At the [[Dominican Order]]'s printing press at [[Abucay Church]] in the [[Philippines]], [[Tomas Pinpin]] prints Father Francisco Blancas de San Jose's ''Arte y Reglas de la Lengua Tagala'' and his assistant Diego Talaghay prints Pinpin's own ''Librong Pagaaralan nang mga Tagalog nang Uicang Castilla'', the first book written by a native Filipino in the local [[Tagalog language]], encouraging his countrymen to learn [[Spanish language|Spanish]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Quirino |first=Carlos |title=The First Philippine Imprints |journal=Journal of History |volume=8 |date=September 1960}}</ref> *[[Lope de Vega]] buys a house in Madrid.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Jean Beguin]] – ''[[Tyrocinium Chymicum]]'' *[[Edmund Bunny]] – {{proper name|''Of Divorce for adulterie and Marrying againe; that there is no sufficient warrant so to do''}} *[[William Camden]] – ''Britannia'', in an enlarged translation by [[Philemon Holland]] into English *''[[Foxe's Book of Martyrs]]'', fourth edition *[[John Healey (writer)|John Healey]] – ''St. Augustine of the Citie of God'', a translation of [[St. Augustine]]'s ''[[City of God (book)|De Civitate Dei]]'' into English *[[:fr:Charles Loyseau|Charles Loyseau]] – ''Traité des ordres et simples dignités''
===Drama=== *[[Samuel Daniel]] – ''Tethys Festival or the Queenes Wake'' ([[masque]]) *[[Lope de Vega]] **''[[:es:La buena guarda|La buena guarda]]'' **''El divino africano'' **''[[:es:La hermosa Ester|La hermosa Ester]]'' *[[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] – ''[[The Faithful Shepherdess]]'' *[[Ben Jonson]] **''[[The Alchemist (play)|The Alchemist]]''<ref>{{cite book |last=Williams |first=Hywel |title=Cassell's Chronology of World History |location=London |publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson |year=2005 |isbn=0-304-35730-8 |pages=243–248}}</ref> **''[[The Speeches at Prince Henry's Barriers]]'' *[[John Marston (poet)|John Marston]] – ''[[Histriomastix (play)|Histriomastix]]'' (published) *John Mason – ''The Turk'' (published) *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[Cymbeline]]''<ref>{{cite book |last=Palmer |first=Alan |author2=Veronica |year=1992 |title=The Chronology of British History |publisher=Century Ltd |location=London |pages= 170–172 |isbn=0-7126-5616-2}}</ref>
===Poetry=== *[[Giles Fletcher]] the younger – ''Christ's Victory and Triumph''
==Births== *[[January 10]] – [[Louis Maimbourg]], French historian (died [[1686 in literature|1686]]) *[[January 15]] (baptised) – [[Sidney Godolphin (poet)|Sidney Godolphin]], English poet, politician and soldier (killed in action [[1643 in literature|1643]]) *[[April 1]] – [[Charles de Saint-Évremond]], French soldier, critic and essayist (died [[1703 in literature|1703]]) *[[July 4]] – [[Paul Scarron]], French poet, dramatist and novelist (died [[1660 in literature|1660]]) *[[July 18]] – [[Antonio de Solís y Ribadeneyra]], Spanish dramatist and historian (died [[1686 in literature|1686]]) *[[July 28]] (baptised) – [[Henry Glapthorne]], English dramatist (died c. 1643) *[[December 18]] – [[Charles du Fresne, sieur du Cange]], French philologist and historian (died [[1688 in literature|1688]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Richard Bulstrode]], English author and soldier (died [[1711 in literature|1711]]) **[[Edmund Chilmead]], English writer and translator (died [[1654 in literature|1654]]) **[[Reinhold Curicke]], German historian of the Hanseatic League (died [[1667 in literature|1667]]) **[[Li Yu (author)|Li Yu]] (李漁), Chinese comic writer (died [[1680 in literature|1680]]) **[[François Eudes de Mézeray]], French historian (died [[1683 in literature|1683]]) **[[Madeleine Patin]], French moralist writer (died [[1682 in literature|1682]]) *''Probable year of birth'' **[[Jeremias de Dekker]], Dutch poet (died [[1666 in literature|1666]]) **[[Jin Shengtan]], born Jin Renrui, Chinese editor, writer and critic (died [[1661 in literature|1661]])
==Deaths== *July – [[Richard Knolles]], English historian (born c. 1545) *[[August 27]] – [[Anne Bacon]], English translator (born c. 1528) *[[September 22]] – [[Jan Moretus]], Flemish printer (born [[1543 in literature|1543]]) *[[November 21]] – [[Benet Canfield]], English mystical writer (born [[1562 in literature|1562]]) *[[November 28]] – [[Lorenzo Scupoli]], Italian theologian (born c. 1530) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Adam Berg (publisher)|Adam Berg]], German printer and publisher (born [[1540 in literature|1540]]) **[[Georgios Chortatzis]], Greek verse dramatist (born c. 1545) **[[Nikola Vitov Gučetić]], Ragusan philosopher and science writer (born [[1549 in literature|1549]]) **[[Bernard de Girard Haillan]], French historian (born c. 1535) **[[Yuan Hongdao]] (袁宏道), Chinese poet (born [[1568 in literature|1568]]) *''Probable year of death'' **[[Peter Bales]], English inventor of shorthand (born [[1547 in literature|1547]]) **[[Philip Stubbs]], English pamphleteer (born c. 1555)
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1610 In Literature}} [[Category:1610 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1888|film}}
The following is an overview of the events of '''1888 in film''', including a list of films released and notable births.
==Events== * [[George Eastman]] files for a patent for his [[photographic film]]. * [[Thomas Edison]] meets with [[Eadweard Muybridge]] who proposes a scheme for [[sound film]] (February 27, [[West Orange, New Jersey]]). * [[Étienne-Jules Marey]] starts work on his ''chronophotographe'' with 90 mm wide roll paper [[film]]. * [[Charles-Émile Reynaud]] is the first to use [[film perforations|perforated]] film for use with his animated show, [[Théâtre Optique]].
==Films== [[File:Roundhay Garden Scene.ogv|thumb|200px|Believed to be the world's earliest surviving motion-picture film.]] *''[[Roundhay Garden Scene]]'' directed by [[Louis Aimé Augustin Le Prince]] is credited by many as the first film but is actually the second film (after ''[[Louis Le Prince#Man Walking Around a Corner (LPCC Type-16)|Man Walking Around A Corner]]'', also by Le Prince). *''[[Louis Le Prince#Traffic Crossing Leeds Bridge (LPCCP Type-1 MkII)|Traffic Crossing Leeds Bridge]]'', directed by [[Louis Le Prince]], is filmed on paper filmstrips. *''[[Louis Le Prince#Accordion_Player (LPCCP Type-1 MkII)|Accordion Player]]'', directed by [[Louis Le Prince]]. *''Pferd und Reiter Springen über ein Hindernis'', directed by [[Ottomar Anschütz]] in [[Germany]]. *''Brighton Street Scene'', a [[lost film]] directed by [[William Friese-Greene]].
==Births== *January 3 **[[George B. Seitz]], American director, writer, actor and producer (died [[1944 in film|1944]]) **[[James Bridie]], Scottish writer (died [[1951 in film|1951]]) *January 17 – [[Edvard Persson]], Swedish actor (died [[1957 in film|1957]]) *January 23 – [[Franklin Pangborn]], American actor (died [[1958 in film|1958]]) *March 4 – [[Rafaela Ottiano]], Italian-born American actress (died [[1942 in film|1942]]) *March 5 – [[Jules Furthman]], American writer, director and producer (died [[1966 in film|1966]]) *March 10 – [[Barry Fitzgerald]], Irish actor (died [[1961 in film|1961]]) *March 30 – [[Anna Q. Nilsson]], Swedish-born American actress (died [[1974 in film|1974]]) *April 11 – [[Donald Calthrop]], English actor (died [[1940 in film|1940]]) *April 27 – [[Florence La Badie]], American actress (died [[1917 in film|1917]]) *May 17 – [[Claude Mérelle]], French actress (died [[1976 in film|1976]]) *May 25 – [[Miles Malleson]], English actor and writer (died [[1969 in film|1969]]) *July 4 – [[Henry Armetta]], Italian-born American actor (died [[1945 in film|1945]]) *July 16 – [[Percy Kilbride]], American actor (died [[1964 in film|1964]]) *August 14 – [[Robert Woolsey]], American actor (died [[1938 in film|1938]]) *August 17 – [[Monty Woolley]], American actor (died [[1963 in film|1963]]) *September 12 – [[Maurice Chevalier]], French actor and singer (died [[1972 in film|1972]]) *September 25 – [[Hanna Ralph]], German actress (died [[1978 in film|1978]]) *September 26 – [[Wally Patch]], English actor and writer (died [[1970 in film|1970]]) *October 1 – [[John E. Blakeley]], English producer, director and writer (died [[1958 in film|1958]]) *October 9 – [[Hank Patterson]], American actor (died [[1975 in film|1975]]) *October 18 – [[Paul Vermoyal]], French actor (died [[1925 in film|1925]]) *October 25 – [[Lester Cuneo]], American actor and producer (died [[1925 in film|1925]]) *November 3 – [[Maurice Vinot]], French actor (died [[1916 in film|1916]]) *November 18 – [[Frances Marion]], American writer, director, producer and actress (died [[1973 in film|1973]]) *November 23 – [[Harpo Marx]], American actor and writer (died [[1964 in film|1964]]) *November 24 – [[Cathleen Nesbitt]], English actress (died [[1982 in film|1982]]) *November 25 – [[Amund Rydland]], Norwegian actor (died [[1967 in film|1967]]) *November 26 – [[Francisco Canaro]], Uruguayan-born Argentine composer, producer and actor (died [[1964 in film|1964]]) *December 6 – [[Will Hay]], English actor, writer and director (died [[1949 in film|1949]]) *December 18 – [[Gladys Cooper]], English actress (died [[1971 in film|1971]]) *December 22 – [[J. Arthur Rank, 1st Baron Rank]], English producer and writer (died [[1972 in film|1972]]) *December 27 **[[Thea von Harbou]], German actress, writer and director (died [[1954 in film|1954]]) **[[Svend Melsing]], Danish actor and playwright (died [[1946 in film|1946]]) *December 28 – [[F. W. Murnau]], German director, writer and producer (died [[1931 in film|1931]])
==External links== {{commons category inline|bullet=none}} * [https://www.imdb.com/Sections/Years/1888 1888] at [[The Internet Movie Database]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox non-profit|name=Art Aia- Creatives/ In/ Residence|image=Art-aia fvg.jpg|abbreviation=Art Aia|type=Italian cultural Center and Artist-in-Residence organization|purpose=[[Cultural exchange]] and [[Artistic practices]]|region=[[Friuli Venezia Giulia]]|affiliations=Art Aia-La Dolce Berlin|website=[https://artaiafvg.wordpress.com/ Official website]|map=https://goo.gl/maps/goMpG7gs1HU2|founder=[[Giovanni Morassutti]]|headquarters=[[Sesto al Reghena]]}}{{DISPLAYTITLE:Art Aia-Creatives/In/Residence}} '''Art Aia - Creatives / In / Residence''' is an international art residency<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ilgazzettino.it/home/art_aia_antica_stalla_diventa_centro_creativo_le_mappe_fluide-606448.html|title=Art Aia, l'antica stalla diventa centro creativo per le Mappe fluide|access-date=2018-07-27}}</ref><ref name=RAI/> located near the ''[[comune]]'' of [[Sesto al Reghena]] in the north-eastern [[Italy|Italian]] region [[Friuli-Venezia Giulia]]. It's a place for artistic production and [[research]] that focuses on the development of the [[creative process]] and facilitates [[Culture|cultural]] exchange across [[border]]s.
==History== Art Aia - Creatives / In / Residence is located three kilometers from Sesto al Reghena, in the locality of "Banduzzo" (which in local dialect means "''Place Banned''") and from the mid-nineteenth century has been an [[Agriculture|agricultural]] center of the Morassutti Family.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipac.regione.fvg.it/aspx/ViewProspEstesa.aspx?idAmb=120&tp=vRAP&pNum=0&idsttem=6&tsk=PG&idScheda=136|title=Patrimonio Culturale-Friuli Venezia Giulia|last=|first=|date=|website=ERPAC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><!-- <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://g.co/kgs/1DULXX|title=Una famiglia e un caso imprenditoriale: i Morassutti - Cerca con Google|website=g.co|language=it-US|access-date=2018-07-27}}</ref> This is bogus! A search engine result is not a valid ref! -->
==The small Church of St. Anthony of Padua== [[File:Art Aia.jpg|thumb|The small Church of St. Anthony of Padua]] In the garden of Art Aia - Creatives / In / Residence stands the nineteenth century Church of St. Anthony of Padua,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sac2.halleysac.it/c093043/zf/index.php/servizi-aggiuntivi/index/index/idtesto/28|title=Comune di Sesto al Reghena|website=sac2.halleysac.it|language=IT|access-date=2018-07-27}}</ref> erected by the owners of these lands and it contains the contemporary altar-piece which represents Saint [[John the Baptist]] and [[Anthony of Padua|Saint Antony of Padua.]]
==Today== Art Aia - Creatives / In / Residence currently promotes [[Culture|cultural]] and [[art]]istic activities at a local and international level. In the past few years several teaching artists have been collaborating with the venue like American Master Drama Teacher [[John Strasberg]], son of [[Lee Strasberg]], who held two International acting workshops<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ricerca.gelocal.it/messaggeroveneto/archivio/messaggeroveneto/2013/08/30/PN_20_44.html|title=Workshop di recitazione con John Strasberg |work=Messaggero Veneto |access-date=2018-07-27|language=it}}</ref> as well as Italo-Palestinian artist [[:it:Mustafa Sabbagh|Mustafa Sabbagh]] who tought a photography masterclass<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://artaiafvg.wordpress.com/press/#jp-carousel-224|title=L'arte del fotografo Sabbagh |date=2015-01-10|via=Art Aia |work=Messaggero Veneto|access-date=2018-07-27|language=IT}}</ref> in 2014. Several [[artist collective]]s have also been hosted in the center like Marsala 11<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.artribune.com/mostre-evento-arte/mappe-fluide/|title=Mappe fluide |date=2014-09-24|work=Artribune|access-date=2018-07-27|language=it-IT}}</ref> and the Institut für Alles Mögliche of Berlin<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ilgazzettino.it/pay/cultura_pay/a_sesto_scambio_di_idee_con_un_picnic_d_artista-2606780.html|title=A Sesto scambio di idee con un picnic d'artista|access-date=2018-07-27}}</ref> among others.
== Venue == [[File:Art Aia Studio.jpg|thumb|Art Aia studio]] Art Aia Creatives / In / Residence has various working spaces<ref name=RAI>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rai.it/dl/portali/site/articolo/ContentItem-51cd7ab1-30d3-435f-8c21-6a31bd980e71.html|title=OBIETTIVO FRIULI|work=Rai Friuli Venezia Giulia Broadcast 26/09/2018- ITA|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref> at the disposal of the visiting artists. Spacious rooms and outdoor spaces are available for production, [[Exhibition|exhibiting]], exchange and leisure, including the Art Aia guest house, the Art Aia [[studio]], the garden, the multi purpose and cross-diciplinary art centre (in progress), the Art Aia [[rehearsal]] space, the fields and the [[vineyard]] where [[Installation art|installations]] and [[performance]]s can be realised.
== Programs ==
; Cross-disciplinary Artist Residency Program
Every summer, Art Aia-Creatives / In / Residence, offers a cross-disciplinary [[Artist-in-residence program|Artist in Residence program]] open to international artists that culminates with an exhibiting event which is generally open to the local public.
'''Arts Territory Exchange Residency in Sustainable Practice'''
Since 2018, Art Aia - Creatives / In / Residence collaborates with the Arts Territory Exchange in the Residency in Sustainable Practice which is an off-shoot programme that has been formed in collaboration with the Centre for Sustainable Practice in the Arts (CSPA). Two artists per year have the opportunity to develop their practices in relation to ideas of [[ecology]] and [[sustainability]] by attending a one week residency at the Italian [[Arts centre|art center]].
== Berlin location == In 2016 was founded<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://artaialadolceberlin.com/imprint/|title=Imprint|date=2016-11-29|work=La Dolce Berlin|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en-US}}</ref> in [[Berlin]], Art Aia-La Dolce Berlin,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://artaialadolceberlin.com/|title=La Dolce Berlin|website=La Dolce Berlin|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref> which is a project space in the [[Turkish people|turkish]] area of [[Wedding (Berlin)|Wedding]] that hosts artists from all over the world and give them an opportunity to showcase their work. Art Aia -La Dolce Berlin promotes Friulian wine<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zingarate.com/germania/berlino/la-dolce-berlin-un-aperitivo-all-insegna-dell-arte.html|title=La dolce Berlin: un aperitivo all’insegna dell’arte|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref> and [[food]] as well and it is the [[Germany|German]] location of Art Aia.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
{{Commons category|Art Aia-Creatives/In/Residence}} *[https://artaiafvg.wordpress.com/ Website of Art Aia- Creatives / In / Residence] *[https://www.transartists.org/air/art-aia-creatives-residence Art Aia on Transartists] *[https://www.thatscontemporary.com/artinresidence/places/art-aia-creativesinresidence/9342/ Art Aia on AIR The Network of residences]

page.title: Arts Council of Winston-Salem Forsyth County

revision.comment: Rescued 3 archive links; remove 3 links. [[User:Green Cardamom/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2013}} {{primary sources|date=October 2013}}
'''The Arts council of Winston-Salem and Forsyth County''', covering [[Winston-Salem, North Carolina|Winston-Salem]] and [[Forsyth County, North Carolina]], USA, claims to have been the first (1949) locally established [[arts council]] in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intothearts.org/about/ |title=About Us | The Arts Council of Winston-Salem & Forsyth County |publisher=The Arts Council of Winston-Salem and Forsyth County |date= |accessdate=October 23, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2009/nov/19/20-mondale/c_1/ |title=Joan Mondale applauds Arts Council of Winston-Salem and Forsyth County |publisher=JournalNow.com |date=November 19, 2009 |accessdate=July 24, 2012}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Now there are more than 4,000. The Arts Council raises funds for the arts, advocates for the arts, sponsors events with other arts organizations, provides educational opportunities, develops [[social capital]], and assists economic development. It relies on volunteers and contributors (both private and public) to run effectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2010/jun/09/090150/no-easy-budget-answers/ |title=No easy city council budget answers|first=Laura |last=Graff |work= Journal Reporter |date=June 9, 2010|accessdate=October 23, 2013}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
The council employs full-time staff members, including CEO Jim Sparrow,<ref>Triad Business Journal Aug 9th,2013 Arts Council names new CEO</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journalnow.com/opinion/editorials/article_5854ee9b-f34e-50d4-ace7-e315e01bca2b.html |title=Milton Rhodes |publisher=JournalNow.com |date=December 20, 2009 |accessdate=July 24, 2012}}</ref> and has a [[Board of Directors]] that makes decisions regarding grant appropriations <ref>{{cite web|last=Keuffel |first=Ken |url=http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2010/may/23/rhodes-is-point-man-for-citys-arts-future/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20100530123639/http://www2.journalnow.com/content/2010/may/23/rhodes-is-point-man-for-citys-arts-future/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=May 30, 2010 |title=Rhodes is point man for city's arts future |publisher=JournalNow.com |date=May 23, 2010 |accessdate=July 24, 2012 }}</ref>
==History== The Arts Council was founded in 1949 with $7,200 in seed money from the Junior League of Winston-Salem. They were the first arts council created in the United States and continue to be a model for similar organizations throughout the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intothearts.org/about/history-of-the-arts-council/ |title=History of the Arts Council |publisher=The Arts Council of Winston-Salem & Forsyth County |date= |accessdate=October 23, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131026174947/http://www.intothearts.org/about/history-of-the-arts-council/ |archivedate=October 26, 2013 }}</ref> In the late 1980s, city and county leaders recognized The Arts Council as the official local arts agency for public arts funding. The organization raises funds on an annual basis to support artists and arts and [[cultural organizations]]. The Arts Council owns its office downtown, the Arts Council Theatre, the Downtown Center for the Arts, and a parking lot.
==Community Impact== The Arts Council states that for 60 years it has aimed to "provide proactive leadership and spark cultural growth." Their sponsored programs provide [[Performing arts education|arts education]] to school children, help artists advance their careers, and help organizations in the community provide performances, exhibits and events throughout the year. It is estimated that annually they reach 500,000 local residents and school children through programs and initiatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intothearts.org/who_we_are/impact.asp |title=Who We Are - Community Impact |publisher=The Arts council of Winston-Salem and Forsyth County |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110424221204/http://www.intothearts.org/who_we_are/impact.asp |archivedate=April 24, 2011 |accessdate=October 23, 2013}}</ref> The arts have a substantial economic impact on Winston-Salem and Forsyth County.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intothearts.org/the-creative-economy/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111101161753/http://www.intothearts.org/the-creative-economy/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 1, 2011 |title=The Creative Economy |publisher=The Arts Council of Winston-Salem & Forsyth County |date= |accessdate=October 23, 2013 }}</ref>
==Grants== The Arts Council gives five different types of [[grants]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.intothearts.org/get-a-grant-for-the-arts/ |title=How to Apply for Grants| publisher=The Arts Council of Winston-Salem & Forsyth County |date=May 3, 2013 |accessdate=October 23, 2013}}</ref> They are listed below.
'''The Organizational Support Grant (OSG)''' * Offers financial support to local arts organizations to assist in the day-to-day operations of the organization
'''The Arts-In-Education Grant (AIE)''' * The program is planned and administered in conjunction with the Winston-Salem/Forsyth County School System<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opendreamensemble.com/support.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111063300/http://www.opendreamensemble.com/support.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=November 11, 2007 |title=Our Supporters |publisher=Open Dream Ensemble |date= |accessdate=February 13, 2012 }}</ref>
'''The Regional Artist Project Grant (RAPG)''' * Offers support to artists in the local community and region * The Regional Artist Project Grant provides financial support to individual artists and small, unincorporated groups of collaborating artists * Given to the following disciplines: [[Music Composition]], [[Film]]/[[Video]], [[Literature]]/[[Playwriting]], [[Choreography]]/[[Dance]], and [[Visual Art]]/[[Craft]]
'''The Advertising Assistance Program (AAP)''' * supported by area [[radio stations]] and print publications
'''Innovative Project Grant (IPG)'''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.intothearts.org/ Arts Council of Winston-Salem Forsyth county website ] * [http://www.cityofthearts.com/ City of the Arts website ]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Arts Council Of Winston-Salem Forsyth County}} [[Category:Arts councils of the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in North Carolina]] [[Category:Forsyth County, North Carolina]] [[Category:1949 establishments in North Carolina]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1949]]

The '''Blue Wool Scale''' measures and calibrates the permanence of colouring [[dye]]s. Traditionally this test was developed for the [[textile]]s industry but it has now been adopted by the [[printing]] industry as measure of [[lightfastness]] of ink colourants.<ref name="ref1">[http://www.gaylord.com/adblock.asp?abid=14017 Textile Fading Card example 1], Gaylord. Retrieved 2010-10-18.</ref><ref name="ref2">[http://www.preservationequipment.com/Store/Products/Equipment-$4-Tools/Instruments-$4-Meters/Textile-Fading-Cards Textile Fading Card example 2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715112636/http://www.preservationequipment.com/Store/Products/Equipment-%244-Tools/Instruments-%244-Meters/Textile-Fading-Cards |date=July 15, 2011 }}, Pel. Retrieved 2010-10-18.</ref>
Normally two identical dye samples are created. One is placed in the dark as the [[Scientific control|control]] and the other is placed in the equivalent of sunlight for a three-month period. A standard bluewool textile fading test card is also placed in the same light conditions as the sample under test. The amount of fading of the sample is then assessed by comparison to the original colour.
A rating between 0 and 8 is awarded by identifying which one of the eight strips on the bluewool standard card has faded to the same extent as the sample under test.<ref name="ref3">[http://apps.webcreate.com/ecom/catalog/product_specific.cfm?ClientID=15&ProductID=23850 Faded Card example] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225043448/http://apps.webcreate.com/ecom/catalog/product_specific.cfm?ClientID=15&ProductID=23850 |date=December 25, 2010 }}, Talas. Retrieved 2010-10-18.</ref><ref name="ref4">[http://www.satra.co.uk/spotlight/download.php?file=spot_0607_light_fastness_testing.pdf Faded Card example], PDF. Retrieved 2010-10-18.</ref>
Zero denotes extremely poor colour fastness whilst a rating of eight is deemed not to have altered from the original and thus credited as being lightfast and permanent.
The [[ultraviolet]] (UV) radiation in light is responsible for ink fading. As the intensity of UV radiation differs from place to place, the ink fading also depends on place. It will be more in areas with more UV radiation and vice versa. This difficulty is overcome by the bluewool testing method. Absolute values of fading will depend on light intensity. Relative values of fading, comparing the sample with the standard blue test strip, will depend less on intensity. For example, if a pigment is rated as "BW5" it can be expected to fade to the same degree as strip number 5 on a bluewool test card, for any specific light exposure. The method of comparison between the sample and a test strip enables accelerated testing to be carried out under intense artificial illumination.
== References == <references/>

revision.comment: Undid revision 844687657 by [[Special:Contributions/Osuska Krteček|Osuska Krteček]] ([[User talk:Osuska Krteček|talk]]) seems to be advertising a college course rather than making a well-cited point
revision.text:
[[File:Boston backbay brownstones.jpg|thumb|Buildings in Back Bay constitute one or two very common building types of the period. Note that the materials and styles can be very different on the same types.]]
'''Building typology''' refers to the study and documentation of a set of buildings which have similarities in their type of function or form. There are two ways of looking at the term "building typology". The first is a functional typology that categorizes buildings into groups by the similarity of their use. A functional building typology under this definition may create groups such as hospitals, schools, and shopping centers (see more examples in the [[list of building types]] by use). The second is a typology that groups buildings according to their forms, which is explained is this article. Formal building typology may be based on configuration, format, or relationships of building to streets and each other. Any single functional type can be subdivided into formal types. For example, the residential functional type may be further subdivided into formal categories such as high rise towers, single family homes, duplexes, and townhouses. The townhouse building is one formal type that has a specific configuration: single units are placed side-by-side with others, vertically oriented up to four stories tall, and facing the street. Many more variations of this formal type are found around the world, each with variations that are the result of local materials, cultural habits, age and technology.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Urban Housing Handbook|last=Firley|first=Eric|publisher=Wiley|year=2009|isbn=|location=Chichester, UK|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> Documenting a type is the process of discovering the elements of similar forms which are the same. Usually building types are distinguished by their basic form, site configuration, and scale, but not their specific architectural style, color, or even precise use.and are related to the era, the culture, and the environment in which they arise.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Architectural Composition and Building Typology|last=Cannigia|first=Gianfranco|last2=Maffei|first2=Gianluigi|publisher=Alinea|year=2001|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The Evolution of Urban Form: Typology for planners and architects|last=Scheer|first=Brenda|publisher=APA Books|year=2010|isbn=|location=Chicago, IL|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref>
==History== The idea of autonomous building types arose in part from the general Enlightenment notion of categorization, a prelude to scientific discovery. At first types were intended as ideal models, which could be variously copied. In this sense types were commonly used forms (a [[basilica]], for example), that were adapted over time in new buildings with quite different uses: from [[Roman Forum|Roman fora]] to early church forms ([[St. Peter's Basilica]]), to 19th century train stations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Architecture of the City|last=Rossi|first=Aldo|publisher=|year=1979|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> The fact that these forms are very similar and are derived from each other is an important way of understanding typology: types are evolved over time and therefor can convey a sense of history or cultural continuity. The idea of building types as formal configurations was enhanced by [[J.N.L. Durand]], who developed two important works, the ''Parallele (1799)'', a huge, handsome book that reproduced plans, elevations and sections of historic buildings at the same scale.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Recueil et paralle des edifices de tout genre anciens et modern|last=Durand|first=Jean-Nicolas-Louis|publisher=Gille|year=1799|isbn=|location=Paris|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> He categorized them by formal types, so that their basic similarities could be recognized. Following this work, Durand also created a second book<ref>{{Cite book|title=Precise of the lectures on architecture, with graphic portion|last=Durand|first=J.N.L|publisher=|year=1802|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> that manipulated and reconfigured the classical elements of architecture—columns, walls, etc. in order to adapt them to new, emerging uses.<ref>{{Cite book|title=J.N.L. Durand (1760-1834): Art and science of architecture|last=Villari|first=Sergio|publisher=Rizzoli International|year=1990|isbn=|location=New York|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> Durand's system, a language of architecture, demonstrated one essential characteristic of types: a way of designing that was neither entirely free of constraint nor overly prescribed.
==Documenting a building type==
Most buildings of any city can be recognized as belonging to a building type. In the US, for example, several residential types exist, such as garden apartments, townhouses, and high rise housing. Each of these may have many subtypes: even within one part of a city there may appear two or three predominant residential types such as a small post-WWII house or a strongly horizontal ranch house. Anyone can begin to identify types simply by observing the common buildings in a place. Architectural and urban designers document types more thoroughly, by measuring them, dating them, noting similar changes to the type that arise over time, and identifying their recurring locations in the city.
==The uses of building typology in history and practice== [[File:Delft Voldersgracht 1.JPG|thumb|Houses along the canal in Delft are a type common just to this area.]] Building types are critical to architects because they are a starting point for designing. One need not reinvent the form if a common building type, say an office building, is wanted. Most architects develop a sense of common building types over time, even without acknowledging their importance. Architects know the approximate dimensions, bulk, site placement, and internal circulation that dictates most types. This allows them to work quickly to determine the parts of the design problem which are unique: material, orientation, structure, specific dimensions, entrance, and so on.<ref name=":1" /> One school of thought in Italy, started by Saverio Muratori, recognizes the importance of typology in providing continuity in the city.<ref name=":0" /> These architects have been influential in recognizing the role of type for modern architecture, where the newest buildings are encouraged to actively assimilate many typological characteristics, without imitating historical styles. [[File:Duxton Road shophouses 2.JPG|thumb|A common type in Asia is the "shophouse" which has an open shop on the ground floor and rooms above for living.]] Historians, anthropologists, and architectural historians use the documentation of type as a key to other characteristics in a city, for example events, political control, or economic changes. As theory tells us, when a type evolves over a period of time, this is an indication that conditions in the city have changed.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Built for change: neighborhood architecture in San Francisco|last=Moudon|first=Anne Vernez|publisher=MIT Press|year=1986|isbn=|location=Cambridge, Massachusetts|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> Anne Moudon documents changes in the types of an Alamo Square<ref name=":2" /> neighborhood to tell a kind architectural, cultural and economic history. She also identifies the block, lot and street pattern as key to typological continuity. Multiple studies using this method have identified important building types, for example Chinese [[shophouse]]s, Shanghai's [[Shikumen]] housing, [[Terraced house|terrace housing]] in Great Britain, [[Courtyard neighborhood|Courtyard]] buildings in France, and the atrium houses found in many hot climates. Atrium types are also important for mosques, shopping malls, and some [[Atrium (architecture)|hotels]].
==Building type and urban design==
Common types are the building blocks of the city. Usually, a neighborhood streets and lots are laid out so that the common type can be built there. This occurs today in suburban subdivisions, but it has been a pattern in history, as well. This combination of types, streets and lots is called an [[urban tissue]],<ref name=":0" /> or a plan unit.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Alnwick, Northumberland: a Study in Town-Plan Analysis|last=Conzen|first=M.R.G.|publisher=Institute of British Geographers|year=1960|isbn=|location=London|pages=|via=}}{{page needed|date=October 2016}}</ref> When studying a city, a designer identifies the common tissue patterns in place and may decide to link to them, imitate them, or otherwise recognize them as an historical artifact. A movement of urban theorists and practitioners in the US, [[New Urbanism]], has identified building typology as a key to defining more user-friendly places. In trying to preserve neighborhoods or building new ones, building types once again become the building blocks of the city, and may be codified in law as [[form-based code]]s.
==References== <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}
[[Category:Architecture]]

revision.text:
[[File:Color solid comparison hsl hsv rgb cone sphere cube cylinder.png|300px|right|thumb|Side-by-side comparison of several different color solids for the HSL, HSV and RGB color models.]]
A '''color solid''' is the three-dimensional representation of a [[color model]], an analog of the two-dimensional [[color wheel]]. The added spatial [[dimension]] allows a color solid to depict an added dimension of [[color]] variation. Whereas a two-dimensional color wheel typically depicts the variables of [[hue]] (red, green, blue, etc.) and [[lightness]] (gradations of light and dark), a color solid adds the variable of [[colorfulness]] (either chroma or saturation), allowing the sphere to depict all conceivable colors in an organized three-dimensional structure.
==Organization==
{{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | total_width = 440 | image1 = Munsell color sphere.png | caption1 = Exterior view of color sphere of [[Albert Henry Munsell]], 1900. | image2 = Atlas of the Munsell Color System page 13.jpg | caption2 = Interior cross section of Munsell's color sphere and color tree, 1915. }} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | total_width = 440 | image1 = Runge Farbenkugel.jpg | caption1 = [[Philipp Otto Runge]]’s ''Farbenkugel'' (color sphere), 1810, showing the surface of the sphere (top two images), and horizontal and vertical cross sections (bottom two images). | image2 = Tape Ball Color Space, Itten, 1919-20.jpg | caption2 = Color sphere of [[Johannes Itten]], 1919-20 }} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | total_width = 440 | image1 = Color Sphere.jpg | caption1 = Color sphere modeled in salt dough by Jesse Hensel, 2011. | image2 = Color Sphere Section.jpg | caption2 = Section of Hensel's sphere revealing a color spectrum. }}
Different color theorists have each designed unique color solids. Many are in the shape of a [[sphere]], whereas others are warped three-dimensional ellipsoid figures—these variations being designed to express some aspect of the relationship of the colors more clearly. The color spheres conceived by [[Phillip Otto Runge]] and [[Johannes Itten]] are typical examples and prototypes for many other color solid schematics.<ref>Johannes Itten, "The Art of Color", 1961. Trans. Ernst Van Haagen. New York: Reinhold Publishing Corporation, 1966. {{ISBN|0-442-24038-4}}.</ref> The models of Runge and Itten are basically identical, and form the basis for the description below.
Pure, saturated hues of equal brightness are located around the equator at the periphery of the color sphere. As in the color wheel, [[Complementary color |contrasting (or complementary) hues]] are located opposite each other. Moving toward the center of the color sphere on the equatorial plane, colors become less and less saturated, until all colors meet at the central [[Coordinate axis|axis]] as a neutral [[gray]]. Moving vertically in the color sphere, colors become lighter (toward the top) and darker (toward the bottom). At the upper pole, all hues meet in white; at the bottom pole, all hues meet in black.
The vertical axis of the color sphere, then, is gray all along its length, varying from [[black]] at the bottom to [[white]] at the top. All pure (saturated) hues are located on the surface of the sphere, varying from light to dark down the color sphere. All impure (unsaturated hues, created by mixing contrasting colors) comprise the sphere's interior, likewise varying in brightness from top to bottom.
== Usage ==
[[Artists]] and art critics find the color solid to be a useful means of organizing the three variables of color—hue, lightness, and saturation (or chroma), as modelled in the [[HCL color space|HCL]] and [[HSV_and_HSL|HSL color models]]—in a single schematic, using it as an aid in the composition and analysis of visual art.
== See also == {{Commons|Category:Color solids|Color solids}} * [[Color model]] * [[Color triangle]] * [[Color wheel]]
== References == <references/>
==External links== * [http://jakobvogel.net/legacy/index.php?url=java/projects/runge/index.xml Runge's Color Sphere] (Java applet does not work in all Web browsers)
{{Color topics}} [[Category:Color]] [[Category:Color space]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} '''Color symbolism''' in [[art]] and [[anthropology]] refers to the use of color as a [[symbol]] in various [[Culture|cultures]]. There is great diversity in the use of colors and their associations between cultures<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Smith|first=N.S. |last2=Whitfield|first2=T.W.A. |last3=Wiltshire|first3=T.J. |date=April 1990 |title=The accuracy of the NCS, DIN, and OSA-UCS colour atlases |journal=Color Research & Application |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=111–116 |doi=10.1002/col.5080150209 |issn=0361-2317}}</ref> and even within the same culture in different time periods.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Color psychology and color therapy: a factual study of the influence of color on human life |last=Birren |first=Faber |date=2006 |publisher=Kessinger Publishing |isbn=978-1425424107 |location=Whitefish, MT |oclc=74452551}}</ref> The same color may have very different associations within the same culture at any time. Diversity in color symbolism occurs because color meanings and symbolism occur on an individual, cultural and universal basis. Color symbolism is also context-dependent and influenced by changes over time.<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Color symbolism |doi=10.5040/9781501303364.ch-014 |title=Color Studies |editor1=Edith Anderson Feisner |editor2=Ronald Reed |edition=3rd |year=2016 |publisher=Bloomsbury |location=New York |isbn=978-1-50130-336-4 |oclc=1053938255 }}</ref> Symbolic representations of religious concepts or articles may include a specific color with which the concept or object is associated.<ref>{{Cite journal |language=de |title=Encyclopaedia Britannica|doi=10.1163/9789004337862_lgbo_com_050367 }}</ref> There is evidence to suggest that colors have been used for this purpose as early as 90,000 BC.{{fact|date=November 2018}}
== Common associations ==
=== Red === Red is often associated with love, passion, and lust. It is frequently used in relation to Valentine's Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.google.com/search?q=valentine&safe=off&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJobTilr7eAhWCLn0KHaP-BZIQ_AUIFCgC&biw=1366&bih=618 |title=valentine - Google Search|website=www.google.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It can also be used to signify danger or warning. For instance, it is used for stop signs<ref>{{Citation|title=Road vertical signs. Variable message traffic signs|publisher=BSI British Standards|doi=10.3403/03263875u}}</ref> and fire engines.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rocklandfirefighters.org/?zone=/unionactive/view_article.cfm&HomeID=50076&page=Fire20Department20Traditions|title=Why are fire trucks red?|website=www.rocklandfirefighters.org|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> In China, red is often used to symbolize good luck or happiness, and is used for many holidays or weddings.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/color-symbolism-in-chinese-culture-what-do-traditional-chinese-colors-mean/|title=Color Symbolism in Chinese Culture: What do Traditional Chinese Colors Mean?|date=2015-01-16|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Blue === Blue is the color of the ocean and the sky; it often symbolizes serenity, stability, or inspiration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-blue/|title=Meaning of The Color Blue {{!}}|last=|first=|date=2011-01-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> It can be a calming color, and symbolize reliability.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.color-meanings.com/blue-color-meaning-the-color-blue/|title=Blue Color Meaning - The Color Blue|last=|first=|date=2013-03-01|work=Color-Meanings.com|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> In the Catholic Church, the Virgin Mary is most often depicted wearing blue, to symbolize her divinity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://aleteia.org/2017/06/24/why-is-the-blessed-virgin-mary-always-wearing-blue/|title=Why is the Blessed Virgin Mary always wearing blue?|last=|first=|date=2017-06-24|work=Aleteia — Catholic Spirituality, Lifestyle, World News, and Culture|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> Blue is widely used for baby boys' clothes or bedrooms, although the reason blue is so strongly associated with boys is debated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.livescience.com/22037-pink-girls-blue-boys.html|title=Why Is Pink for Girls and Blue for Boys?|date=1 August 2012|first=Natalie|last=Wolchover|work=Live Science|access-date=7 November 2018}}</ref>
=== Yellow === Yellow is a color often associated with sunshine or joy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colormatters.com/the-meanings-of-colors/yellow|title=Yellow|last=Morton|first=Jill|website=www.colormatters.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It is sometimes used in association with cowardice or fear, i.e, the phrase "yellow-bellied".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vocabulary.com/dictionary/yellow-bellied|title=yellow-bellied - Dictionary Definition|work=Vocabulary.com|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref> Children tend to like this color, and it is used to market products to children;<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-yellow/|title=Meaning of The Color Yellow {{!}}|date=2011-02-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> it is also used for school buses and taxi cabs since it is such a bright, noticeable color.<ref name=":0" />
=== Green === Green is most often used to represent nature, healing, or fertility, since it's such a dominant color in nature. It can be a very relaxing color<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-green/|title=Meaning of The Color Green {{!}}|date=2011-01-25|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> but is also used in the US to symbolize money, greed, or jealousy.<ref name=":1" /> Saying that someone is "green" means they're inexperienced or new.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/green|title=Green definition and meaning {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
=== Black === Black, in Western culture, is considered a negative color and usually symbolizes death, grief, or evil.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.colorpsychology.org/black/|title=Black Color Psychology - Black Meaning & Personality|work=Color Psychology|access-date=2018-11-05|language=en-US}}</ref> People often wear black for mourning, although this practice isn't as wide-spread as it was in the past.<ref>{{Citation|last=Jalland|first=Pat|date=1996-11-07|pages=77–97|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198201885|doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198201885.003.0005|title=Death in the Victorian Family|chapter=Death and the Victorian Doctors}}</ref>
=== White === White most often symbolizes perfection, faith, innocence, softness, and cleanliness.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-white/|title=Meaning of The Color White {{!}}|date=2010-12-05|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> Brides often wear white dresses to symbolize virginity or purity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bridesmagazine.co.uk/article/why-do-brides-wear-white|title=Why Do Brides Wear White? And Other Questions|last=Davis|first=Lexxi|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
=== Pink === Pink is associated with softness, femininity, sweetness, and love.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bourncreative.com/meaning-of-the-color-pink/|title=Meaning of The Color Pink {{!}}|date=2010-11-15|work=Bourn Creative|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref> However, it was formerly used as a masculine color, frequently used for baby boys; it wasn't until the early 20th century that the gender roles of pink and blue were reversed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/12/health/colorscope-pink-boy-girl-gender/index.html|title=The complicated gender history of pink|last=Ant|first=Puja Bhattacharjee, CNN Animation by Giant|work=CNN|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
==Color symbolism in marketing== Color plays an important role in setting expectations for a product and communicating its key characteristics.<ref name=Asiam>{{Cite journal |last=Aslam |first=Mubeen M. |date=2006 |title=Are You Selling the Right Colour? A Cross‐Cultural Review of Colour as a Marketing Cue |journal=Journal of Marketing Communications |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=15–30 |doi=10.1080/13527260500247827}}</ref> Color is the second most important element that allows consumers to identify brand packaging.<ref name=Popa>{{Cite journal|last=Popa|first=C.N. |last2=Popescu|first2=S. |last3=Berehoiu|first3=R.M.T. |last4=Berehoiu|first4=S.M.T. |date=2013 |title=Considerations regarding use and role of colour in marketing |url=http://managementjournal.usamv.ro/pdf/vol.XIII/Art44.pdf |journal= Scientific Papers Series - Management, Economic Engineering in Agriculture and Rural Development |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=269–274}}</ref>
Marketers for products with an international market navigate the color symbolism variances between cultures with targeted advertising. The car manufacturer, Volkswagen ran a commercial in Italy with a black sheep in the middle of a larger flock symbolizing those who owned a VW Golf as someone unique and self-assured among a crowd of others who were not. In several cultures around the world, a black sheep represents an outcast and is seen as something undesirable. In Italy, a black sheep represents confidence and independence.[[File:Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017.jpg|thumb|Friaul Val Aupa Drentus Sheep credit Kaspar Nickles 2017]] There are many additional variances in color symbolism between cultures. Cold is symbolized by blue in East Asia, the USA, and Sweden while warmth is symbolized by yellow in the USA and by blue in The Netherlands. Sometimes the meanings of colors are in stark opposition across geographic boundaries, requiring products marketed to specific demographics to account for those changes across different markets. For instance, feminity is symbolized by blue in The Netherlands and pink in the USA., whereas masculinity is symbolized by blue in Sweden and the USA, and red in the UK and France.<ref name=Asiam/> In some instances color symbolism in marketing is constructed. For companies whose products are defined by the name of their color their sales are susceptible to the symbolism and association of that name. In one example, a company selling a paint color named “off white” more than doubled its sales by renaming the same color as “ancient silk.”<ref name=Popa/>
==Conceptualizations of colors cross-culturally== Color symbolism has morphed over time. Between the 5th and 17th centuries color was largely related to in a religious context. Blue was symbolic of heaven and white of purity. Today, purity is still symbolized by white in Australia and the USA but by blue in other countries like India. Similarly, the church influenced the perception of colors like crimson and purple. Largely because the dyes for these colors could only be sourced from precious pigments, religious figures like Madonna, Cardinals, and the Virgin were seen in scarlet and purple. [[File:Vatican II - Dubois - Liénart.JPG|thumb|Vatican II - Dubois - Liénart]]Today, purple symbolizes evil and infidelity in Japan, but the same is symbolized by blue in East Asia and by yellow in France. Additionally, the sacred color of Hindu and Buddhist monks is orange. [[File:Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap.jpg|thumb|Preah Pithu T Monks - Siem Reap]] The Renaissance was also a time in which black and purple were colors of mourning. Today, Mourning or death is symbolized by white in East Asia, black in the USA, and blue in Iran, while happiness is symbolized by white in Australia and NZ, and yellow in China.<ref name=Asiam/>
There is a general disagreement over whether reactions to color and their symbolism are a result of cultural conditioning or of instinct. Several studies concluded that color is part of the social learning process because of the significant symbolism within the culture. High quality, trustworthiness and dependability are symbolized by blue in the USA, Japan, Korea and green and yellow in China - as well as purple in China, South Korea and Japan. Because of these variances, critical cues vary across cultures. Warning signs are coded differently as danger is symbolized by green in Malaysia, and red in the USA and Mexico. The same color of green symbolizes envy in Belgium and the USA, but envy is symbolized by yellow in Germany and Russia, and purple in Mexico. Even the colors that denote powerful emotions vary. Love is symbolized by green in Japan, red and purple in China, Korea, Japan and the USA. Unluckiness is symbolized by red in Chad, Nigeria and Germany. Luckiness is symbolized by red in China, Denmark and Argentina. The traditional bridal color is red in China and white in the USA. Ambition and desire are symbolized by red in India.<ref name=Asiam/>
== Color symbolism in Arabic culture == Color has different meanings in different countries. We can specifically look at the Arabic culture and take it into consideration. We can start with the color white. In the Arabic culture, white is thought of as the color that is symbolic for nature. Since it related with nature, it has a meaning that is one of positivity. It also relates with that of being clean and pure. White is a color that is commonly worn during prayers and with that, it symbolizes purity. White’s positive connotation carries out into other aspects. It is also used as a symbol for positivity in the future. White is also used to symbolize the end of war. You will also see women adorn white at their weddings as a sign of positivity. Since doves are white, they share the symbolic meaning that comes with the color. This in turn causes them to be associated with positivity of good news.
When you look at the color Black in Arabic culture you can find that it is related to funerals and death. Women will often wear black to funerals in order to show that they are sad for those who have passed. Also relating to death, black is associated with hell. Black is also used to symbolize dark. Hell is thought to be a dark black place associating black as negative. Black in general is looked at as having negative connotations around it. For example, the symbolism of a black heart refers to someone who is unkind. [[File:Red rose with black background.jpg|thumb]] Green is a color that is commonly found in Islam. It is a color found in nature and with this, it is associated with and represents goodness. Green is a color that has an overall positive meaning. The color green also has to do with truthfulness, again going with positivity. If you look at phrases, the symbolic meanings are generally positive. If you look at the phrase green hand, it relates to being generous which is a positive thing.
Red has an overall positive association with it. Often you will find that red is a color associated with roses and blood. The color red has to do with love and passion. In sayings you can find it to have either a negative or positive meaning such as the term red eye relates with anger. The Arabic culture also associates this color with death.
Blue is related with positivity when discussing it with nature, otherwise it can be related with negative connotations. When used in the phrase blue eyes, it refers to jealousy. A blue body relates with death and therefore is associated with negativity.
Yellow is another color that is also associated with nature and the sun. Again, since it is a color related with nature, it takes on the symbolic meaning of positivity. Gold is also categorized under here and is also takes on a positive meaning. Generally, when used in phrases, the color yellow has to do with negativity. For example, a yellow smile means to be mean.
<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hasan|first=Amna|date=2011|title=How Colours are Semantically Construed in the Arabic and English Culture: A Comparative study|url=https://files.eric.ed.gov/fulltext/EJ1080712.pdf|journal=English Language Teaching|volume=4|pages=206–213|via=}}</ref> ==Colors and emotions== [[File:Emotions - 3.png|thumb]] Color symbolism is displayed in many ways. One of the most common ways we see color symbolism displayed in through our emotions. In this article Color-emotions associations: Past experience and personal preference it takes a look at how we connect colors with our emotions and how it depends on a person’s preference and or their past experiences. This article first starts out by talking about the different colors and what they are associated with. The first color it talks about is the color blue and how people see blue as comfort and security and how they see orange as being upsetting. The next one they talk about is yellow which is more of a happy color compared to purple which they say is dignified but I have never heard of purple being seen that way. The next one this article talks about which I find very interesting is the color red. People view the color red in two different ways, one being as a strong and passionate color. However, it is also seen in a very different way, people see it as an aggressive color because it is the color of blood. The last color this article talks about is the color green and how just like red it has two different views. Green can be viewed positively as in quietness but can also be viewed negatively as in guilt. This study took a look at how we associate colors with emotions. This study was done and showed that we associated lighter colors such as blue or yellow with more positive emotions. It then showed how we associated darker colors such as grey or black with more native emotions. However, something very interesting that this study did find is that most young prefer the color black over many other colors. The study was done with college aged students to see how they associate their emotions with colors. Many tests were done such as matching tasks and matching color tests to see what colors they associate with their emotions. The study had 44 men and 54 women in it and they again were all college students. They identified a color sample with one emotion only and it showed what emotional response is connected to a color. The results from this study did find that people mostly associate the color green with being the most positive. Over 95% off people said that green s the most positive because it makes them feel relaxed and then comfortable and at peace. It also showed that people saw yellow as the more excited and energetic emotion, with over 90% agreeing with this. 79% of students found that blue was a calming color because it reminded them of the ocean which is known as a calming place. People did have different answers when it came to red because like explained earlier, red is seen in two very different ways, It has been seen as love by many but also as evil because it remind people of blood. Many people did not seem to like the color purple very much as it was not favored by many for their preferences. The color black was seen to be more negative emotions like fear and depression. Overall, this article shows how color can be important because it is how people associate their emotions and things based on color symbolism.<ref>Kaya & H., Naz & Helen. Color-emotion association: Past experience and personal preference. The University of Georgia, Department of Textiles, Merchandising, and Interiors, 2004.</ref> <ref>{{Cite web | url=https://books.google.com/?id=lCoAb9RDVIYC&pg=PA31&dq=color+symbolism+#v=onepage&q=color%20symbolism&f=false | title=AIC 2004 Color and Paints, Interim Meeting of the International Color Association, Proceedings}}</ref>
